results.notes: Growing in leaf litter on a ridge near red oak, white oak, beech, black cherry and sugar maple. Caps sticky and often covered in dirt. Stem dry and pruinose at the apex. Gills decurrent, waxy and yellowing in age. Odor indistinct to slightly fishy in age. No bruising reaction. No veil present in any stage of development. Fruiting bodies clustered to scattered. Some fruiting bodies joined at the base with 1 to 2 other fruiting bodies. Context white. Very abundant in a roughly 10 square foot area. results.notes:
Growing in moss and grass at the base of a young Abies balsamea var. phanerolepis in a plantation of that species. Scattered and in small clusters of up to 3. Odor radish-like. Taste mealy. Caps convex. Caps slimy, chestnut brown in the center and cream on the margin. Cap margins slightly inrolled when young. Caps not rugulose. Did not seem to be hygrophanous. No cortina or universal veil present. Gills sinuate and without tears or a white fimbriate edge. Young gills white, become light brown in age. Gills ~0.2 cm deep. Stem pruinose at the apex and slightly enlarged at the base. Context white to opaque and slightly hollow in the center of the stem. Did not notice discoloring or mycelial cords. Spore print dull brown.

results.notes: Found as a single mushroom beside an asphalt road in a grassy culvert. Surroundings mixed conifer/hardwood. Cap peaked-conical split in one place, Reddish orange near top becoming orange wih a faint greenish cast near the margin, glabrous, moist but not slimy, margin even. I can’t see striations by eye. Gills close, white, narrowly attached, bruising black. Stem ca.8cm length, yellowish, solid, fibrous when cut longitudinally halfway then pulled apart to the base., roughly rectangular/ovoid in cross section and twisted, even to the base. The cap and stem and context of stem all bruise black. I’m callng this H. singeri because the stem felt slimy, but that is the only criterion. Kuo uses that to discriminate it from H. conica.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1026/2016_DSC6356

Habitat: mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; skeletal, colluvial, calcareous ground; in shade; relatively warm and dry place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 560 m (1.840 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: on soil, covered by forest ground humus, mainly rotten leaves of Fagus sylvatica.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, near Skokar farm house, Trenta 2, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Naming members of genus Tuber is a problem for me. Different sources have different approaches. I am following Index Fungorum (current name Rhizopogon aestivus (former Tuber aestivum)). This disagrees with MycoBank and Ref.: 2, 6 and 7. Also, according to Ref.:2, molecular analysis showed no differences between Tuber aestivum and Tuber uncinatum. Therefore they are synonymized or T. uncinatum considered as a variety as a variety of T. aestivum. Another taxon – Tuber mesentericum – is very similar to Tuber aestivum. When old they are hard to separate (Ref.2). They have been synonymized or considered a Tuber aestivum variety by some authors; however molecular analysis showed that they are two different species (Ref.2).

Macro and micro traits of this find correspond well to Rhizopogon aestivus = Tuber aestivum. However, a possibility that the find is Tuber mesentericum cannot be completely excluded according to Ref.2. Although a hypogeous fungus, I found it only half-buried in forest ground humus and Fagus sylvatica leaves. I noticed it without any digging. This sometimes happens when animals dig them for food and then leave them there uneaten. Tuber aestivum is mycorrhizal with roots of several trees, almost certainly with Fagus sylvatica in this find. But when fruitbody becomes larger than about 1 cm in diameter they can thrive further also on ground as a saprophytic fungus (Ref.:1).

Orange blobs on the surface of the Tuber are a parasitic anamorph fungus. The fusiform conidia obviously belong to genus Fusarium (Ref.:3).

Growing solitary; fruitbody quite old (over-mature), 38 mm across; surface covered with black, large, 4-6 sized pyramidal warts; no cavity at the bottom seen; the pattern of white veins seen in cross-section does not correspond well to usual pattern for this species (too few and too coarse), but this can be explained by over-maturity of the fruitbody (numerous fine veins disappear with age according to Ref.: 1); smell indistinctive, not strong, which often happens with over-ripen fruitbodies (Ref.:2); taste not tested; spore mass dark brown, almost black.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
Leratiomyces ceres (Agaricales, Strophariaceae) Bogotá, Colombia
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/40641362
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/50875899

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

Basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, el Píleo mide entre 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse hacia el borde, con escamas fasciculadas originadas por restos del velo universal que forma un círculo a modo de collar cerca del borde. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, pruinoso. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

Primer registro de esta especie para Colombia. Segun Vasco-Palacios AM, Franco-Molano AE. 2013, la familia Strophariaceae esta representada por las siguientes especies:

results.notes:
Growing in dense clusters at the base of a Tilia tree in black mulch near the edge of a path. Taxus bushes further away. Odor radish-like but not very strong. Taste mealy. Caps convex. Caps dark brown in the center and white at the margin. Young caps with a patchwork pattern of lighter-colored spots. Caps not hygrophanous and without universal veil remnants. Cap margins inrolled. Lamellae adnate with white fimbriate edges and without tears. Lamellae about 0.3 cm deep. Base of stem tapered or around the same width as the rest of the stem. Stem pruinose at the apex. Context white with opaque areas. Stem not discoloring or rooting and without mycelial cords. Cortina present.

results.notes:
Growing in a cluster of 3 under 2 unknwown bushed near a Tilia tree near a sidewalk. Odor funky and somewhat cheese like although this could be due to age. Taste mealy. Caps convex. Caps light brown in the center and white at the margin. Caps did not appear to be hygrophanous and lacked universal veil remnants. Cap margins inrolled. Lamellae adnate with white fimbriate edges and without tears. Lamellae about 0.4 cm deep. Base of stem slightly bulbous, Stem pruinose over much of its lenght and especially so at the apex. Context white. Stem not discoloring or rooting and without mycelial cords. Cortina not present on the specimens I found.

results.notes:
On what appears to be calcareous sandstone outcrop in semi-arid grassland setting.

Thallus consists of light yellowish brown convex shiny areoles, widely dispersed, with areas near apothecia darkening reddish, cortex minutely pitted, C+R (hardly discernible), KC+R (again, hardly discernible), without pruina. Apothecia sunken in areoles, basically one per, with thalline margin (parathecium?) swollen and raised around disk making the disk look small and puckered (yes, some do resemble sphincters!), disk dark reddish brown, without pruina. Hymenium hyaline, about 100µm tall. Epihymenium light to reddish brown.

results.notes:
I am not sure about this hygrocybe. Found under ca bay laurel, in chaparral intergrading to black oak woodland. Emergent ponderosa pine nearby. The only hygrocybe previously observed at Big Chico Creek Ecological Reserve was flavescens. I have found 5 of this specimen now, from 3 sites. The cap is always conical like singeri, the color is similar (bright yellows and rich warm orange). the size is large compared to singeri I have found at other sites and there is never staining black. Does singeri always stain black?
Updating the BCCER species list so any help is appreciated.

results.notes:
On siliceous rock in a boulder pile created by historic farming practices of clearing the fields. Habitat is semi-arid grassland with nearby ephemeral drainages and blue oak woodland.

Thallus dark slate grey, looks black to the naked eye, without marginal lobes, prothallus absent. Apothecia abundant, superficial, lecanorine, thalline margin dominant & concolorous with thallus, disk looks black but has reddish brown tint, K+violet or purplish. Hymenium hyaline, epihymenium brown, K-.

8/ascus, hyaline, polarilocular with a wide septum:
17.7×8.8
15.9×6.5
14.1×5.5
16.3×8.1µm

I definitely did not consider Caloplaca for this. I’ve been seeing sterile thallus material of this for a while now but hadn’t found any good mature fertile specimens.

results.notes:
On an intruded bedrock outcrop of siliceous rock, mostly serpentine, in a semi-arid grassland setting.

Thallus grey, areolate, when mature margins lift off substrate appearing slightly lobed but not subumbilicate. Areoles 0.6-1.0mm (approx), separated by cracks, K-. Apothecia one per areole, 0.4-0.7mm (approx), disk black, thalline margin grey, thin. Hymenium hyaline, epihymenium brown, K-.

Spores 8/ascus, brown, 1-septate, without bands. The locules appeared mostly round, and were not observed to be ornamented. I thought these were probably Bicincta Type, but to be R. gennarii they should be Dirinaria Type. Measurements of a couple spores:
17.0×8.6
19.1×7.5
18.7×8.9

results.notes:
In damp grassy pitch pine area with sandy soil.

Spore shape seems wrong for Panaeolus (evenly elliptical, not lemon-shaped), and under the scope the spores are not solidly black. Spore print appeared to be black, but when the glass slide was placed over a black background a dark purple tinge was observed. No mammal dung observed in this area, but I didn’t examine the area closely.

Gills blackish with mottled appearance.

Spores elliptical 9-14 × 6-8.

Found late in the day, so flash was necessary to get a useful photo of the gills.

I’m guessing Hypholoma or Psilocybe. H. dispersum has smaller spores and H. elongatum has gills reportedly not as dark as these. But despite the spores not reminding me of Panaeolus, I think this is still a possibility.
